title: several remote code execution vulnurabilities found !!!!
body:
several remote code execution vulnurabilities found !!!! 
This allow stealing etherum directly from the main node without any need for conformation with the client.
the poc is a simple javascript snippet that can be easily embedded on any site and causing users who navigate to the site to loose all "security" when the etherum is installed to the default directory or when useng web3 client like metamsk.
the severity of this is far greater then i could explain here or on the bounty site - i guess that is why i wasnt rewarded for finding the vulnuraibilty?
either way the only way i found so far to fix it is changing the installtion to some unknown folder so that the wallet.dat file cannot be retrived or by encripting the wallet.
is using a db like my sql for security - doesnt help as the snippet can easily be modified for remote code excution allowing the "hacker" to just copy the entire wallet and steal all funds.
the poc is actully taken from another type of vulnurabilty based on simple xss on wordpress sites - allowing theft of files on edd installations - either way if i dont see the bounty reward ill have no choice but to publish the poc in 2 days time for the sake of your users.
i guess that is what happens when a group of web developer create a project like ethereum - no security inspection?!

although id be far happier to recieve the bounty in fiat currency to my paypal as it cannot be hacked this easily: pablorotem8@gmail.com

to all users and developers of etherum - id suggest to change the installation forlder on the local machine / server - and possibly use encription for the wallet to fix this security issue!

>i guess that is why i wasnt rewarded for finding the vulnuraibilty?

We have received no such report via either bounty@ethereum.org nor the bounty-form. 

> folder so that the wallet.dat file cannot be retrived

No ethereum client I know of uses a `wallet.dat` file. 

> or by encripting the wallet

All ethereum mainnet clients uses encrypted keystore files

> and possibly use encription for the wallet 

Again, keystore files are encrypted. 

I have no idea what you think you have found, or if this is just trolling. If you believe you have found something relevant, then please file a report to bounty@ethereum.org (or via https://bounty.ethereum.org).
